Simply can't recommend this game. A big part of the immersive sim genre depends on feeling like everything is part of a curated experience. In Deux Ex/Prey/Dishonored you can learn enemy behavior, patrol patterns, have several different lethal/nonlethal options, several big and small ways to change your method of progress. There is dialogue and meaningful choices and logs and lore and worldbuilding integrated in every encounter. Some encounters might have you face traps, be solved entirely with dialogue, have you take long alternating routes using skills like breaking down walls, teleporting or whatever the game gives you. Isometric RPGs in general go a step further, giving nearly every NPC (including enemies) their own stories, quests and personalities. I hoped (probably stupidly) this might be a sort of mix.This game does absolutely none of that. 99% of the game feels procedurally generated. Every town feels like a copy-paste, every quest/bounty is a fetch/kill quest for random items from random people. Characters, even the main characters, are entirely devoid of meaningful personality. There are very few lore books and newspapers seem procedurally generated. Things happen in the world with seemingly no meaningful connection to your actions. The "immersive sim" parts are limited to specific encounters (I saw one in 7 hours of gameplay) and it still boiled down to "use one of these 4 curated methods to achieve goal A". Combat is the same corridors towards a target against the same handful of enemies, usually wandering about with no defined patrols, your options being "non-lethal melee that can fail for god knows what reason"/"Stealth kill"/"Shoot everything with slow-mo dodge roll". The longer you play, the more often you will wonder why you don't choose option 3 all the time.There are a lot of other poor design choices (progression in both items and skills is nearly meaningless, difficulty is all over the place, you are not encouraged to engage with a lot of systems because progression is meaningless, companions are TERRIBLE) but the core of the issue remains that an immersive sim NEEDS to feel like a carefully designed playground, the game bouncing different approaches back at you and constantly surprising you, forcing you to adapt. The moment everything is a procedurally generated encounter with the same handful of enemy types, it loses any appeal to me.
Keep on keeping on

I've already 100% completed (achievement wise) the original iteration of DS here on steam a little less than 2 years ago, and Director's Cut has now finally arrived. At somewhat of a good time too because I've just now started to get the itch to replay the game from start to finish again. While I haven't gotten to the point to test out all the new endgame toys this edition adds, I have noticed that the starting experience is more streamlined in a good way. The new player experience is a less arduous than before with some more tutorials like on planning out your first route to help with adjusting to the gameplay loop. Also the maser gun and support exoskeleton help ease some of the frustrations in the early game when you're still in the east coast area. This is especially so if you decide to grind it out a bit before moving into the "mid-game" so to speak. These additions seamlessly find their way into regular progression and feel like they were always there to begin with.While some people hated and meme'd the product placement with Monster, I really didn't mind and always found Kojima's inclusion of stuff like this more amusing than anything in all his games. But that is gone and replaced by Bridges energy. I think the variety of graphic upscalers like Nvidia's DLSS (The latest version as of release), AMD's FSR, and eventually Intel's XeSS is great and will allow people with older hardware to get a better visual experience while getting more FPS for smoother gameplay. Before with the original we had a more primitive form of DLSS that had some ghosting and visual artifacting issues. Now those are gone and DLSS now mirrors native presentation quality so there's almost no excuse to not have it on since it gives you higher framerates especially if you're playing above 1080p.I also noticed the soundtrack has expanded with more music in some of the ambient moments while trekking the land. They are great additions and match the mood of the other tracks. Not gonna lie I was afraid Hoshino Gen's 'Pop Virus' would be removed for the Director's Cut but it's still here. I always put that on my PCC structures since it's such a catchy J-Pop song haha. That's neither here or there though. Overall from what I can tell the changes are very subtle which in some ways is a good thing because the original DS truth be told was a complete experience already sans the tedious early game. On the other hand it's slightly disappointing because I kind of wanted more. But most of the implementation of what is new from my initial impressions feel like they were thought out and not just tacked on for no reason. As I mentioned the new stuff added so far feels like they were always there which is a good sign progression and immersion wise.I transferred a new save I barely started from the original game and most of the achievements transferred over which is kind of nice. Just some progression stuff I need to grind for because it's a fairly fresh save, which is fine, I was planning on getting those things anyways again in this new playthrough. For people who have had their fill of DS and have no desire of playing again the new stuff isn't really enough to justify coming back. But if you've been itching to play again after being away from the game for awhile Director's Cut will be a fun nostalgic experience with some added bells and whistles. For new players, well this is the only version of DS you can play anyways since the old version got delisted lol. But it is from what I can see the definitive version of the game so it is worth a purchase if you're curious about Death Stranding but haven't gotten a chance to buy/try it yet. Plus the retail price is now only 39.99 USD (Can't speak for regional pricing), but should be discounted nicely in future steam sales. For people who have bought the original DS, you only need to pay 9.99 USD to get this new version. I think it's a fair upgrade price content wise especially considering all of the predatory overpriced DLC out there when it comes to games. So you can buy with confidence old players and new.For a quick and dirty review, DS is a very unique experience to say the least. It's not for everyone but can be both super calming to play and equally suspenseful when you encounter BTs or Mules. The story can sometimes feel a bit overdramatic in a stage theater kind of way, but at the same time it has something genuine and heartwarming to say. The landscapes you'll trek are breathtaking and I think the view distance in Director's Cut is farther than in the original which adds to the scale and makes the world feel even larger. Is DS a walking sim? Why yes it is, the best damn walking sim out there too especially since it actually tries to mechanically simulate walking. MOCAP, and the general acting performance from the star studded cast is immaculate especially in the cinematic cutscenes. Playtime will vary but I would guesstimate for most people 40 - 60 hours depending on how much you engage with the side content or take your time. Also while I love Metal Gear, I think DS is Kojima's best work to date, and is a really special experience. Hope whoever plays DS will find something that resonates with them along the way and "keep on, keeping on!"

Every third spring, a solo indie developer reinvents Sokoban.Okay, well, this certainly isn't as hard as Baba or Stephen's Sausage Roll but it's just as inventive and creative, and it's also, importantly, incredibly funny. I don't think puzzle design has ever made me laugh as hard as this game. The concepts are introduced and toyed with then integrated into future concepts smoothly, rarely do ideas feel repeated, there's a -ton- of puzzles and the challenge puzzles can get quite tricky, the aesthetic is polished and pleasant to look at, it's just an overall really clever and enjoyable puzzle game with.... no real downside to speak of, other than that it's not going to wreck your brain or stump you in the same ways as similar games, and that [ispoiler]there's no real meta-puzzle aspect to the game, it is just a long sequence of levels with no real twist[/ispoiler] but that second one is... well, really a nitpick, the game is compelling enough as-is that it didn't necessarily -need- that extra push to be awesome.

If you don't already own Baba is You I don't recommend you buy this game. I can't give this game a negative review because the concept is so clever and the mechanics are so thoroughly executed, but I felt pretty let down. It took me 9 hours to beat all the 300 main levels, at the time of this review I haven't finished all the challenge levels but I'm not super excited to play them except for the achievement.It only took me about 2 minutes per puzzle but the vast majority of them took far less than that, usually I would quickly finish 2-4 puzzles in a row then spend 15 on one puzzle, but the ones which I spent more time on didn't feel harder I just think I wasn't able to see the solution very quickly. Almost all the puzzles either introduce a new or clever trick, or they make you do that trick multiple times. Sometimes doing it multiple times requires more thinking but often it doesn't. It felt exhausting to finish all the levels, when I spent a long time on one puzzle only to find the clever trick I felt more stupid than accomplished or just lucky after trying nearly every possible way to push the blocks into each other. I think this would probably be a better game if you just took the best 100 levels. It felt like the 300 levels in the game were the first 300 levels ever made and in a hurry. Most of them can't really be adjusted to be better the only way to improve the quality of the levels would be to create another 500 levels then throw away all the ones that aren't excellent. As a quick comparison Baba is You took me about 35 hours to finish 223 puzzles which is about 9 minutes per puzzle. I felt like the hard puzzles where objectively hard and were very satisfying. It's crazy to think that the mechanics from Baba is You and Patrick's Parabox could theoretically overlap perfectly in a single game but that's just a dream at the moment. Anyway here's my final thoughtsPatricks Parabox - 7.5/10 - $20Baba is You - 9.4/10 - $15Sure 9 hours is definitely worth the $20 but I would probably wouldn't be nearly as critical if it was $10.

This is the first time in a while that I've felt compelled and capable to 100% a puzzle game on my own. It's a complex and difficult game, but also very fair and forgiving in ways that make it a joy to play. Puzzles are difficult because of how they re-use and re-contextualize their mechanics, rather than adding additional layers of complexity for the sake of difficulty. Solutions tend not to be particularly long. I think of the 364 puzzles, there was a total of one that I did not understand and had to brute force. That's pretty remarkable!In addition to all that, I think there's a lot of value in playing this game for the first time blind. Every time a new mechanic is introduced, it was a surprise to me - and yet, the mechanic was simple enough that I almost instantly understood it.I do not know if you'll enjoy this game to the end if you're not a puzzle game enjoyer. However, if you are, I cannot recommend it enough.

This game has a lot going for it!-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------I've waited until the game's full release to write this. As of today I have 179 hours in this, and I've beaten the game 4 times. I think I can write this review pretty confidently lol.I bought this game after seeing Civvie's 2 videos on it. It looked like so much fun I had to try it...before I knew it, it was 2am and I had no intention of stopping. Even now, it remains just as enjoyably addictive. This is just as well, because the game goes on forever. Literally, forever. With the Chapter 3 update, New Game + was implemented, and you can play this game with progressively stronger weapons and enemies for as long as you want. Even if you don't decide to play NG+, you've still got at least 50 hours of levels and bossfights- that's about how long it took me to finish the game for the first time.But what about the details, Mantha, the DETAILS?! Very well: 3 game-modes, 3 minigames, 3 chapters, featuring 80+ levels, with 80+ weapons, and 50 enemies, officially-speaking. Technically, there are 25x as many levels, if you count all their variations (each level has a set of variations you can encounter. If you die and retry a level, the layout will be different), and for the weapons, there's...technically, there's like 1000+. All the different combinations of modifiers (including my favorite, "Random projectile") make for very, VERY different weapons. For instance, on one of my saves, I have a shotgun that shoots explosive fireballs. Another shotgun I have uses explosive pellets that deal shock damage. Yet another shotgun I had is able to shoot on automatic, has 3 extra shells, and does ice damage, which can freeze enemies solid. So in reality, the amount of different weapons in Nightmare Reaper is innumerable. As you can probably tell, this aspect of the game is my favorite. I I love collecting new, wild, powerful weapons in games, especially when each one feels and sounds satisfying, as they do in Nightmare Reaper.Speaking of sounds, have you *heard* the soundtrack for this game? Listen to the trailers, watch someone stream the game. The music is fantastic and matches the mood of the dream-based slaughterfest...oh would you look at that, it's by Andrew Hulshult. That explains it. As for other, non-musical sounds, the weapons all sound gorgeous (the sawed-off's alt-fire is how every shotgun should sound), to the point that sometimes I start using a weapon not because it has particularly strong modifiers, but because dammit, I really love the way it sounds. You will also enjoy the sounds of the enemies, who each have various idle sounds, alert sounds, pain sounds, and death sounds, all of which make the killing even more satisfying.How about the graphics? Every game's gotta have shmexy graffix, right? Nightmare Reaper does not disappoint. Its pixel-heavy retro style may put off the zoomers who have no appreciation for art, but for those who understand the uniqueness of old-school sprites and textures, this game delivers. Modern lighting and shading techniques coupled with lovingly-made textures give each level its own particular atmosphere that you simply have to play to fully feel. ...Okay, this section of the review sounds like a snobby game journalist wrote it, but I stand by my words! It looks great. One of my favorite things to do is to sneak up on enemies and just study the way they look. Gaunt, the man responsible for the enemy designs, made some eerily, disgustingly-beautiful creatures.What about the story? What is all this dream stuff about? Why are you in a mental asylum? Who are you? Da ♥♥♥ is going on? If you've read my reviews before you know I abhor spoiling a story, so don't expect any. You play as an unnamed young woman who has lived a...rough life...and has developed some serious mental scarring that's left her with a struggling grip on reality. She experiences vivid nightmares, in which the player can find small clues and hints as to her past, and how she got to this place in her life. During her waking hours, she is left notes by her doctor, which serve to explain the story in more concrete terms. Ultimately, the battle for sanity is fought in her dreams.Lastly, I want to talk about the smaller, less fundamental things. The game has lots of settings, so you can customize graphics, UI, controls, and even gameplay to a fair extent. The minigames act like skill trees, helping you become more powerful and gain new abilities, so they aren't just bland bonus features. There is also an arena mode, where you can take the outrageous weapons you find in the proper levels and test your might against endless waves, while also earning currency to spend in one of the minigame skill trees. There are also secrets to find in the nightmare levels, most containing various references, and upon clearing out a large room of enemies, special "events" can occur...some good, some not so good. The game keeps you on your toes! And finally, perhaps the best aspect of this game, its community. The Nightmare Reaper community, specifically the Discord server, is a joy to hang out in and be a part of. It's especially fun talking to the developers...even if the lead dev has some questionable hot takes on movies here and there...and seeing people post clips and images from their experiences in the game. To conclude this lengthy lad of a review...Nightmare Reaper is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ awesome and anyone who enjoys the FPS genre should try it. Seriously, it's that much fun that I can confidently give a broad and sweeping recommendation like that. If you enjoy running around, playing with fun weapons, jumping, shooting, and fighting monsters, you will very likely enjoy this game, especially as the levels grow larger and more complex. It's fun to play, it's full of good music and satisfying sounds, it's got lots of those "little touches" that make it all the more enjoyable, and the community surrounding the game is a big ol' family of videogame nerds. What's not to like? :DTo ItBurn: Congrats on finally finishing your passion project. I hope you take a well-earned rest after this. I wish you the best of luck in future endeavors, and if you ever need a beta tester for them, I'd sign up again in a heartbeat.

"Fountains of crimson pixels are my nightmare fuel.” Nightmare Reaper represents a first-person shooter (FPS) developed and published by the company Blazing Bit Games. Pros & cons: ++ It begins with an uncommon claymore, continues with a rare howitzer, and escalates further, where wielding a legendary grimoire of infernal origin is no longer a curiosity, but part of a never ending array of randomly generated items with various statistics. An addictive loop and main motivation to keep moving forward.+ A smart upgrade system, hidden behind in-game platformers, allows for sufficient number tweaking to your advantage, including abilities and features from more than 20 years of FPS gaming.+ Andrew Hulshult strikes again! His soundtrack contributes to the fast-paced freak show like a proper adrenaline rush.-  Do yourself a favour and ignore the plot; there is little content anyway. Just make sure to check out the hospital once you kill a boss, in order to unlock the arenas [thanks to WorldWarWiesel for pointing it out]. Summary: Being an insane patient in a mental hospital, while fighting for survival in nightmarish episodes, has never been so entertaining. Experimenting with the sheer endless variety of weapons and their ever-changing modifiers is the main attraction of the game. And to my utmost satisfaction it keeps me royally entertained.Recommended for retro FPS gamers and fetishists of crimson pixels. Achievements: Estimated time for 100% completion: +100 hoursSingleplayer achievements: 149Multiplayer achievements: none

However, the idea that this was assembled by a playtested team as opposed to one person who probably couldn't get enough feedback meant is what gave me the open mind to give it a fair-shake. The end result was me being amazed at how tight and clean the balance feels on all 8 classes. I was going to make a standout-list of my top 3, but I actually struggle to decide which are my top 3, which is impressive, considering that in base-game, I could rank the 4 vanilla characters in order from most preferable to least. The map is absolutely gorgeous and detail-rich, I've played alot of games set in Shibuya and this rendition blows everything out of the water by order of magnitudes. It is quite simply one of the best maps I've ever seen in a videogame.But that's where the good things end. This is a game entirely carried by its environment. The combat is underdeveloped and gets dull quickly, there's barely any enemy variety, the open world activities are basically a bunch of ubisoft tier collectathons, and the story feels like a complete afterthought with how uninteresting it is.It feels like what happened here is that they made the map and then realized they had to make a game around it, so they scrambled to fill it up with content and shipped it as soon as possible. This is a rushed product, not in the usual sense of being buggy, but in the sense that its core concepts haven't been developed enough.I'd love to see Ghostwire becoming a series that takes us to different places across the world with their local environment und culture on display, but before that can happen, Tango Gameworks has to sit down and rework the mechanics of Ghostwire. Make the combat deep and engaging beyond some sparkly animations. Give us a great range of different enemies that we actually have to approach differently from each other. Invest time into making a compelling story with interesting characters. And make open-world content that makes the exploration of your beautiful worlds even more fun rather than less so. Ghostwire has alot of potential and can become a great game series, but as it currently stands it's not there yet. Final verdict: great map, mediocre gameplay. 5/10Buy it if you want to walk through Shibuya, but otherwise your time and money is better spent elsewhere.

This is more of a Maybe, but you know steam.At it's core, it's a beautiful and well polished game, with enjoyable combat, an amazing atmosphere, and a lot of unique ideas.  It focuses around Japanese folklore, which normally I don't care about, but it makes each new discovery interesting.  It then adds on a huge amount of collectibles of various types, randomly hidden all throughout the city, which improve your character in some way - which can be discouraging for some, but I found it engagingUnfortunately, that's part of the problem; I did a lot of the sidequests, and collected a lot of things.  I'm now 8 hours in and have fully upgraded all my combat abilities, and I don't think there's really anywhere left to go.  This is what combat is going to be like for the next 30 hours or so.  Which is sorta fine, because it's still enjoyable, but I'm not sure it will be enjoyable 30 hours later.  Otherwise, many of the quests are also very hollow; they exist only to show you some creature from folklore, and then you hold down the 'absorb power' button and it dies and you get a reward.The rewards also stop feeling rewarding when you see that after 8 hours of meticulously grabbing every one you find, you're at 20,000/250,000 And speaking of finding things - you get an ability with no cooldown, that lets you see any interactable object, or enemy, through walls in any direction, for quite a long distance.  This makes the collectible business trivial and tedious; every few steps you stop, press the hotkey, look around/up/down/everywhere, try to figure out if any of the dozen outlines currently being shown are anything useful, move forward a few more steps, repeatSo, it's a maybe for me.  I still plan to keep going with it, and just avoid/ignore the collectibles, and see how it all plays out.  And on its surface, it really does look and feel great.  I just have suspicions that it can't keep up the pace for another 30 hours, especially now that my tech tree is already basically full

This game is one giant collectathon which suits me just fine. I am a wicked scavenger so I love hunting for things and the search is thrilling to me. In truth I had the most fun running around the city searching every nook and cranny for every last trinket and critter and I was successful in finding them all. I also enjoyed the flavour text and reading all the descriptions and KK Notes in full. I know this can be boring and tedious to some people but that's why if you want to not bother with it, you can just play through the story. The story is of a mad scientist and his efforts into separating the soul from the body  but focused around a young man fused with a ghost who was one such soul separating from his body. They team up to kick ass and reverse the separation and put everyone back into their bodies. It's a very quick story to get through and the ending got me super emotional. Tears lined my face I tell ya! I would be interested in a sequel of sorts to see if Akito (young man protagonist) continues to vanquish otherwordly foes or help those with spirit problems. Definitely room to expand the world or leave it as it is.I think it's a lovely game for sure. It balances campy with grit very nicely but won't be a game for everyone. Which is something that can be said for all games really. Do give it a go if what I said entices you. :)

★☆☆☆☆ TerribleFar Cry 2: TokyoThis is without a doubt the most disappointing game I've played this year.First off, I went into this game with the perfect mindset. There is so much wrong in this game that I can't understand how someone could give this high ratings. There is not a single pinch of love put into this game that I can feel. It feels like the only person that really wanted to make the game was Ikumi Nakamura (the ex creative director of the game) and when she left, the other devs were forced to finish this game which created this cesspool of a video game.When I saw the combat through the gameplay trailers, I was excited. It looks great and the animations are badass then I saw the amount of elements and I was like "Wow, can't wait to see what other badass attacks I can throw at my enemies". The fact that there are only 3 elements and each of them only has 2 attacks, light and heavy. THAT IS IT. For a 10 hours game, this is pathetic. The skill tree is a joke. Even with there being only 3 elements, I was still somewhat optimistic. The upgrades are boring and dreadful. "Increase the width of your water element attack from 1m to 2m". There's also nothing for the melee department. There isn't anything like summoning a fire sword that you can use against enemies. This is creatively bankrupt and it shocks me that the man who made this studio was Shinji Mikami. It is embarrassing that his name is now put into this game.The combat also doesn't improve with the poor array of enemy types. The enemies have cool designs even tho most of them look identical. The way their attacks are choreographed are all quite different. The flaw here is that 95% of enemies require the same way to kill which is by spamming everything you have at it. Only one enemy that actually forced me to change elements and that is the fat shield guys because you gotta use the water elements since it's like shotgun. This just makes combat way more bland than it already is. This world is the definition of empty. The map screen is so cluttered with icons: there are telephone booths everywhere in this game, why did the developers have the need to place all of them on the map screen? Same goes for the flying demons. They felt like they need to show everything on the map, no matter how badly it effects the experience as a whole.The worst aspects of this open world is definitely collecting spirits. There are a total of 240000 spirits you need to collect (probably 35-40 hours of all game). How do you collect spirits you may ask? Well, you hold the right mouse button. You do this for every single spirit you find. And then there's the side quest which I gave them a chance. In this game, you talk to random souls that all have the exact same design. There is absolutely no way for anyone to be interested in whatever is happening to these people.95% of buildings in this game you can not enter and when there are, it is stopped by a loading screen and you're teleported into the building. What year is this? Am I back in 2012? Even Yakuza Kiwami fixed this problem long ago. What a joke.Story: the most generic anime plot to ever exist. Blank protagonist who cares for his blank of a sister who is working with a blank detective to save Tokyo from a blank villain. That's the best way I can put this story. The acting is also weak, the amount of overacting in this one is hilarious and no scene will even touch your emotions.Ghostwire: Tokyo the only way to describe the game comes in mind = colossal disappointment!

I'm now 8 hours in and have fully upgraded all my combat abilities, and I don't think there's really anywhere left to go.  This is what combat is going to be like for the next 30 hours or so.  Which is sorta fine, because it's still enjoyable, but I'm not sure it will be enjoyable 30 hours later.  Otherwise, many of the quests are also very hollow; they exist only to show you some creature from folklore, and then you hold down the 'absorb power' button and it dies and you get a reward.The rewards also stop feeling rewarding when you see that after 8 hours of meticulously grabbing every one you find, you're at 20,000/250,000 And speaking of finding things - you get an ability with no cooldown, that lets you see any interactable object, or enemy, through walls in any direction, for quite a long distance.  This makes the collectible business trivial and tedious; every few steps you stop, press the hotkey, look around/up/down/everywhere, try to figure out if any of the dozen outlines currently being shown are anything useful, move forward a few more steps, repeatSo, it's a maybe for me.  I still plan to keep going with it, and just avoid/ignore the collectibles, and see how it all plays out.  And on its surface, it really does look and feel great.  I just have suspicions that it can't keep up the pace for another 30 hours, especially now that my tech tree is already basically full

IntroductionAnimal Shelter is a first-person perspective simulator with the primary goal of operating and maintaining an animal shelter that rescues cats and dogs, and allows you to find them new homes. 🟩 Positives 🟥 Negatives 🟩 Relaxing gameplay.🟩 A moderate quantity of dog and cat breeds to look after.🟩 Your facility is simply modular, allowing you to choose where rooms are placed.🟩 Finding animals a good home is emotionally rewarding.  🟥 Ugly animal models.🟥 Lack of any storyline basically ensures you have no goals to work toward.🟥 The gameplay loop is exceptionally repetitive, with very little to bolster your experience in terms of activities.🟥 Limited customisation.🟥 Animal behaviours don't offer you any varying challenge at all.StoryTo my great dismay, there isn't one. You own and operate an animal shelter that you can personally name, but there isn't any information about your character's motivations for opening one or why they choose to rescue only dogs and cats, and not any other types of animals.Gameplay AnalysisEvery dog (and cat) has its day.The gameplay elements that are present are exceptionally clean and well-thought-out. Unfortunately, the clear downfall is that there aren't many of them. You will begin the game following a rather basic tutorial of how things work: ordering food and water, buying cleaning utensils, taking pictures of the pet, playing with, and looking after them, etc. All of this with the expectation that they will become happier and healthier and eventually be ready to go to a good home that you have personally selected.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2790210259Once you have fare-welled your first animal (be they a cat or dog, as you get the choice at the beginning), you expect the game to open up and provide you with some kind-of fleshed-out experience with plenty of progression and customisation. And that is where the game loses any traction as there is nothing more to it. The only decent addition is that you get limited control over how the shelter will expand, but that's more like fluff content than anything substantial to challenge you, as the customisation of the facility is extremely basic. These upgrades only really serve to make your more gruelling tasks a lot easier and don't add any more things to manage.The only major aspect that I thought might provide some variance to the otherwise stale loop was the animal behaviours, where some are energetic, some are aggressive, and so on. It was seemingly a forgotten mechanic as it doesn't play any part in looking after the pet at all. Every animal you take in will have the same generic AI and doesn't change in the slightest during the entire playtime. The only thing this does for you is that it helps you choose the type of home it should go to, and that is it.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2790210577Audio and VisualFrom a visual standpoint, Animal Shelter has a lot going for it. The environments are detailed and engaging, and the surrounding nature is eye-catching, with lush and highly-detailed foliage decorating the horizon in all directions. And then you go to your loving new companion, and they look like someone glued fur to a pig hoping to trick you into rescuing it. It is such an ordeal, that something as simple as trying to get a decent photo of them for the website is a nightmare all on its own.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2790210441The audio isn't a whole lot better. A bland and flavourless soundboard has been used here with a limited scope of variance. All the dogs sound the same, and all the animation effects sound recycled and empty of any real depth. You get the immediate impression that they weren't recorded for a simulation-style experience. The soundtrack is perhaps the only positive aspect here, as it is soothing and provides you with a tranquil experience as you potter around doing whatever you plan to do for the day.PC Performance and SpecificationsWith the game set to the highest possible settings, I never noticed the framerate drop below 60. There was a surprisingly limited quantity of bugs and glitches during this experience, but I did have at least two crashes in the frame of approximately 5 hours.🟧 Graphical quality is mediocre even at the highest setting.🟨 A couple of early crashes made it hard to want to invest time.RAM: 32GB (Under Load Usage: 34%)CPU: i9 10900KA 3.70GHz (Under Load Usage: 37%)GPU: MSI Ventus RTX 3080 (Under Load Usage: 40.4%)Final Thoughts - BorderlineReview chart here.Animal Shelter isn't going to win any awards for simulator of the year, that's for sure. But the overall experience isn't terrible, it lacks any significant graphical polish or gameplay mechanic that will help break the monotonous loop, but it is a very soothing experience that gives a good insight into what it's like to work in a real animal shelter. I think this game would benefit from some kind-of customisation and varying gameplay, but at the moment, it just doesn't support it.I cannot recommend buying this game at full price, as it simply isn't a full game (yet?). I can, however, happily recommend it to an animal lover who can find it at a severe discount.Follow our Curator page,  Summit Reviews  , to see more high-quality reviews regularly.

Animal ShelterT O O  M U C H  C U T E N E S S ! !Almost all the games I play are filled with violence. On the other hand, Animal Shelter overflows with wholesome vibes only. It was a completely different experience from the usual bloodshed & slaughter games. This game was very exciting to play at first. But after the game shows you all its trump cards, it starts becoming repetitive & boring. Well, at least for me it did. You might have a completely different take on this game! It was nice to see the developers donating 10 grand from their income to animal shelters in real life! My hope for humanity is restored.About This Game Storyline There’s no storyline for the game. You just have objectives to achieve. You take in dogs/cats, tend to them then put them up for adoption. You just have to repeat this over & over again. Yes, there is variety in the dogs & cats since they have different characteristics & varying needs & wants. But the core gameplay feels very repetitive.Gameplay Mechanics I am sure you guys would've played at least one of those “Simulator” games. Well, if you didn’t, lemme explain it a bit. These games try to replicate the experience of a particular job in most cases. For instance, this game gives the player insight into how it feels to own an Animal Shelter. It might not be very accurate but it covers the basics. When you start this game, you get thrown into a tutorial. This lasts for a long time as the game has a lot of features. The game goes something like this: You have to first choose what animal you want to start with; A dog or a cat.  After choosing, you spawn into the game’s world. A van brings in your first stray animal.  Each animal you get has different characteristics & varying needs & wants. As an Animal Shelter, you have to tend to these needs & wants to make the animal happy.  These may include food, water, medical attention, clean up, playing with it, etc. Catering to these needs will improve the dog’s physical & mental health allowing you to put it up for adoption.  You need to buy a camera to take pictures of the dogs which will then be uploaded along with the advert for its adoption. After uploading the Advertisement, you play the waiting game waiting for the perfect client to adopt the dog. This is decided by comparing the traits & features of both, the dog & the client. The more they have in common, the more reputation points you get. You can send a person from your animal shelter to go & investigate the client for more information.  Through the computer, you can choose each animal you want to take in. After selecting, the same blue van will come & deliver the pets to you.  Then the game basically repeats these steps.So, that’s basically how you play the game. It’s repetitive after a while but you can never get enough of these fluffy animals! The interactions are very cute. You can play with the animals & even pet them. What surprised me is that you can pet the animal after placing it in the van which will take them to the new owner. It’s a very emotional detail if you get emotionally attached to one of the pets. Some animals you get will either have an injury or will be sick. You can treat them at the med bay if they are injured. If they are sick, you have to take a blood sample & submit it to the Vet who will send you a prescription of what you need to use to heal that animal. Money management is very important. It’s best to buy supplies whenever you need them since the drone delivers them in 10 seconds. I really love how they used drones to deliver stuff in disposable cardboard boxes which can also be used as storage for extra stuff. You can get expansion tickets by earning reputation stars. These tickets can be used to expand the area of your animal shelter, allowing you to build more buildings. You will need more dog & cat enclosures if you are going to be taking in a lot of them!See, there are a lot of things you can do but the game still gets stale after the tutorial. There are also a few bugs you will encounter like disappearing items, animals clipping through walls, etc. Some mechanics like picking up the animals, the dogs chasing the ball, etc feel a bit too janky. I am sure they will slowly rectify all the bugs & glitches the game has!Visuals & AudioThe visuals aren’t that appealing but animals look cute in any resolution! The game feels low poly. The animations of the animals are very cute! I love how the dogs react when petting them & how the cats chase the lasers. What’s really appealing is the usage of drawings of cute dogs & cats on the loading screen & a drawing of a sad cat & dog in the pause menu with a speech bubble that has “YOU GOIN’, FREN?”. It’s so cute & sad at the same time. Doesn’t allow me to exit the game, hence why I just Alt-F4. In conclusion, the game's visuals are not that great & could use some polishing. On the other hand, their UI design is pretty eye-catching.I forgot to mention that the game gives pretty low FPS. I guess the developers haven’t properly optimized the game. It overheats my laptop & has a lot of FPS drops. Please look into this!Sound design, there’s nothing much apart from Background music, animals barking or meowing, the honk of the van & the whirring of the blades of the Quadcopter. All of them have been perfectly implemented!Pros Cute animals. I love the animations that the dogs & cats have. They’re just adorable. A lot of content. The game is endless. It’s a bit detailed as it takes into account the basic needs of the animals.  The graphics are decent. The animals look low poly when compared to the other hard surface assets, but they oddly suit the game’s vibes. Cons Gameplay gets repetitive & stale real quick.  Few bugs & glitches, no game is perfect.ConclusionI needed a cute & wholesome break and this game gave that to me. I honestly had fun while playing it although I got bored of it. I will surely go back to the game in the future though. Kudos to this indie dev for making a pretty good game! I recommend giving it a shot if you love dogs & cats. In my opinion, the game is not worth the base price. Try grabbing it at a sale. If they add more content that doesn’t allow the game to become stale quickly, then it would be worth the $19.99!Reviewer: MidplayzDogs come when they’re called; cats take the message & get back to you later…Rating: 8/10 Please follow United Critics for more quality reviews.

I was unable to finish the story due to the main quest irreparably breaking, thus barring me from the final area 25 hours in. The price of around 17€ is reasonable for this content amount, however this doesn't matter when all the other issues come into play.Verdict: BadRating Chart HereAn insipid, soulless, generic farming sim that, despite years in Early Access, is still far from the quality standards of a full release. Shocking!In NPLH you'll play as Ellen, an aspiring Mars colonist that decides to go back to an ecologically-ruined Earth and start a new life, trying to set things right instead of abandoning the planet, alongside her grandfather. Turns out the old man disappeared, so you'll have to help out the few locals that chose staying behind like him, and understand what happened to him. Heaps of trash and crazed robots dominate most landscapes, a result of mankind's outrageous conduct; despite the premise, the settings aren't bleak at all between cute animals (sometimes sentient, for a dash of fantasy...) and bright colors. If this is the post-apocalypse, it doesn't look too grim;  lore and writing feel rather generic, as none of the characters or quests will stick in your mind or really hook players at any point - mostly uneventful.A Woman of Many TalentsYou'll be doing mainly two things in this title: clearing each area from trash using your industrial drills and vacuum, and manage the farm. Despite the biome variations, each area plays out exactly in the same way: (slowly) clear trash, collect everything that drops, open chests, push buttons to open gates, bash robots that attack you... always the same two types, slow, weak, badly animated and with death having no penalty whatsoever. There's no variety, be it in the first or last areas, except the occasional timed buttons or mini puzzle: highly-unusual findings. Quests for NPCs mainly consist in gathering X amount of a resource, going from point A to point B or helping X amount of animals by feeding or herding them - also in this case, missions feel too similar and have no interesting variations at any point.A good number of upgrades like increased vacuum range, drills potency, etc. can be purchased using Preserved Food (currency) alongside specific resources (mostly farm products) - they're marginal improvements that aren't really needed given how miserable enemies are; they won't make the cleaning ops much faster either, except when they allow breaking harder mounds of trash, which is mandatory to progress past some areas.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2782502164No Time For Friends, Sigma Grindset Engaged!Most farming sims have relations or even romance options with the various characters, other than activities to do alongside them; let's take the famous Stardew Valley, or My Time at Portia as references, to name a couple. Here there is none of that: NPCs act as glorified, static quest "dispensers" with some random dialogue options for lore's sake, and integrated shops for new machines / facilities for the farm. This completely cuts out any attachment the player may hope to develop towards the characters, and makes the story as a whole, a glorified series of chores.The Painful Life of Post-Apocalypse FarmersWhile it's initially satisfying to set up your own farm freely, or renovating gramps' old house with furniture, wall paper and other amenities, soon the farming side of things will take an annoying, bleak turn indeed. with the locations divided in "compartments" instead of a smooth open-world, you'll end up without space for facilities end crops, thus develop your farm over several "sections" of the world with a loading screen between each. The normal quality-of-life basic systems such as auto-sorting or auto-stacking are absent, chests can't be marked or named, animals clip into each other and have to be manually harvested for resources - very fun when you have 45 chickens and 30 pigs in five square meters. This all amounts to a tremendous slog of fidgeting with interfaces half the time, misclicks and general annoyance.The farm isn't even that engaging to take care of: crops won't die if you forget to water them, rather not grow. Animals are self-feeding and immortal; automatic systems to water everything are unlocked soon enough, so you can stay away for days without caring, and just go back to dump loot when your backpack is full. Cooking is completely useless, as processing raw materials is just faster to gain Preserved Food, while Trash to recycle is ever-abundant - you won't need the various buffs (speed, damage etc.) food gives anyway, given how easy combat is. The various Tier 2 and 3 machines, expensive and locked behind blueprints, are just redundant and not worth the hassle, as you can build five Tier 1 machines, recyclers to name one, and get the same (or better in some cases) efficiency for half the total cost. Once you set up fields, facilities and everything, even just Tier 1, you are already as good as done with the farm, no more meaningful evolution from that point onward... just redundancies.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2783504114All The Wrong Choices Led to ThisYou can see the lines between the various "tiles" that compose the map. Fall through the map itself at times, get stuck in collisions and have to fast-travel back to fix yourself. Animations? What are those? Better make that gate just disappear as soon as the button is pressed, same for huge blocks of ice, boulders or you-name-it. Break enough trash in an area and see your FPS plummet even with a high-end GPU, as each bit of trash is a standalone physics-enabled object, all with Playstation 2-era graphics, amazing! Did I mention the main quest broke permanently, barring me from finishing the game? Yeah, that should give you the idea of this "1.0" release's state.

TLDR: I can't recommend it in the state it's in right now, which is a shame. It's a cool concept, but poorly implemented at the moment. Settings are wonky, controls feel sluggish, there's some serious problems with seeing the attack zones of enemies (and I'm not color blind, so if I'm struggling with it people who are red/green colorblind are going to have huge issues), quests seemed to trigger out of order, and one I was on refused to finish. I hope these issues get addressed, and I will definitely be checking in at a later date, but for now it's very much "early access."The good: It's cute. Everything about it is cute, and it has a decent sense of humor without reaching an "oh god why" level. The music is pretty good, and the sounds fit what you're doing. I consider it a good thing when I can turn off the music and not feel the rest of the soundscape is distracting.The meh: The gameplay (at least as far as I got) seems very shallow. Plant crops, water them, harvest. Befriend animal, wait, harvest from it, fill whatever need it has, then wait again. Drill pile of junk, suck up loose trash, put into recycler and wait. Use the currency you get from that to build new buildings. Buy new buildings with food preserved from what you grew. The foundation for a simple but enjoyable gameplay loop is there, it's just unpolished and maybe unfinished. Expect your first few days to fairly slow on the "getting stuff done" front. (And be sure to go into the house to sleep away the night. That wasn't explained to me, I stumbled on it after walking past the stairs and seeing them light up.)The bad: Pacing is off - I either encountered things far earlier than I was introduced to them, or discovered things long before the quest meant to tell me they existed, and some things just outright were not explained to me at all. I don't mind a game that lets me just go explore, but it didn't set itself up as such through the quest system. The moment you enter the farm area, you're told to talk to an NPC and begin their quest line, with no hint that nothing is (as far as I could tell) locked behind finishing it, and all the implication that you need to do this before you can do anything else. Controls are sluggish at times and you WILL need to fix the mouse sensitivity as soon as you load up the game - it doesn't default to 1 for some reason.End TLDRControls: It feels like it's optimized for controller right now, but it defaults to mouse and keyboard even with a controller plugged in. Mouse sensitivity is set incredibly low, and it's split between the X and Y axis. For some reason I started out with both X and Y set to 0.3, and I ended up feeling ok with 1.5 but probably could have taken it to 2.0 for better results. Unfortunately, mouse sensitivity does nothing for movement controls. All of that is thrown out the window when you activate your drill, though - tank controls engage, including incredibly slow movement. Reach of the drill is *just* short enough you can't finish off a junk pile without moving, and there's *just* enough of a delay between letting up and it actually turning off that quick reactions to get out of the way of an enemy attack is spotty at best. That assumes you can see the attack icons, though - I had things set to Medium and they all blended into the ground, even the red icon. I only spotted the green icon when I knew there was an attack coming and where I should be looking for it - there's no way I would have seen it otherwise. I feel for anyone who is red/green colorblind and trying to play this game.The default keybind mapping is odd and threw me off at first, then just annoyed me. The only standard keybinds are M for the map, and 1-0 for your hotbar. There is no jump, but instead of leaving spacebar unbound it's defaulted to "vacuum" instead. Your mileage may vary, but I was ready to change the bind by the end of my 1.5 hours because I kept doing my usual "jump when I'm walking somewhere" thing and annoying myself with the sound. Both E and R are used for very common actions, but I didn't notice Q doing anything for some reason. Tab is your menu key, but annoyingly messes with the Shift + Tab bind to bring up the Steam overlay. I had a few times where it cancelled the overlay and only brought up my menu, which was not what I wanted.Oh and the mouse cursor is captive to the screen in all window settings, at least when I played. I didn't see a way to turn that off, and so needed the Steam overlay to escape the window without alt tabbing completely. Hopefully this QOL bit will change at some point, but it's common enough I don't really think it's a deal breaker, just something worth mentioning.Pacing: A good portion of what is a deal breaker to me is the pacing. When you start, you find a ton of junk that is very satisfying to clean up, but you have very little direction to do so. Your first quest is to put down a chicken coop and befriend 5 chickens. Nothing is said about the potatoes you can plant, or how you'll want to get those going early on so you have 5 potatoes to befriend said chickens. Likewise, nothing is said about the piles of junk or any of the obviously special crafting materials you'll be getting from cleaning them up. Turns out most (all?) of those are quest items for later! While it's good that you can get them even before getting the quest to collect them, I have to wonder why you are required to clean up so much of the junk just to find all the chickens if you're going to be getting quests for these items later. Quest items jumping ahead of the quest feels... odd.I also completed a quest to put a hat on a chicken before receiving it - and got the "quest finished" dialogue pop up, which confused me because I had thought I'd just discovered a cute cosmetic mechanic. Thankfully doing so didn't break the quest chain, despite 'turning in' that quest before being told to go do it.The quest that did break, and that finally frustrated me enough to just quit, was the "bring proof you've befriended a chicken" quest. I have eggs, I have a chicken feather, but neither of them in any combination will complete the quest. There is zero help for what else you might need to do, even when you go back and ask for a reminder or hint. The quest log didn't have anything useful, either. So either it's broken here, or so vague about a specific that I just couldn't find what it wanted from me. Either one is not good.I'll be watching to see where this goes, but there's enough small issues adding up to keep me from enjoying it overall.

I try to support / give the benefit of the doubt to one man indie studios - but in the case of No Place Like Home it just isn't polished enough to recommend. A complete lack of any QA and testing really shows, but it could have been good maybe with another few months of development or another pair of eyes. It's a farming game, but set in a sort of WALL-E era Earth where there's piles of junk cluttering every inch of the map. The mechanics revolve around clearing the junk, watering plants & animals, then turning your produce into currency to buy upgrades. A good loop and fairly relaxing if you can see past the flaws, but there are just too many of those to bother finishing it.Pros- Hoovering up rubbish is cathartic, but repetitive- You're equipped with a vacuum / hose - which is used to clear rubbish, attack enemies and water crops- Some quests clean up the landscape - actually completely change the colour scheme from dirty brown to fresh green and update all the buildings & decor. Seeing your efforts have an effect is really nice- The areas are beautiful- Fast travel system- Relaxing gameplay loop of clearing trash, farming crops and feeding animals- A decent amount of buildings- An upgrade systemCons- On first boot, mouse sensitivity is super low and may put a lot of people off- The controls for hoovering, planting and collecting plants, interacting with animals are really clunky- The interface lacks polish. When talking to NPCs, sometimes the hover effects on the buttons for dialogue choices don't work, and the continue / interact buttons are in different places- There are no seasons, so ending a day and starting a new one has literally no down side and just fast forwards time- Lots and lots of instances / loading screens- No Steam achievements- You can only cook one of a meal at a time. This is tedious if you're trying to cook 10, or say 50 meals to get currency- Lots of invisible walls- You can't interact with anything even a tiny bit higher or lower than you. There are very few completely flat areas, which means lots of moving up and down trying to get to the right level to interact with somethingBugs- The biggest one here is spelling and grammar mistakes all over the place. Even in the first few dialogues I noticed: "peet food", "turn it int to", "fast travel tunels", "prepaer some cusine". "I will give you a Kennel build it mon the farm", "becasue", "sotries" and "piggy buisness"- Multiple music tracks sometimes play at the same time- Music abruptly stops when you start talking to some NPCs- Quests can be done out of order. I found Harold and got him to be a client of the shop before Mark asked me to do it. Then - Harold asked me to rebuild his house, standing in front of his brand new house- The performance could be better. It's generally really bad when there's a lot of trash on the screen, and my main motivator for tidying the whole map is to improve the FPS- There's an enemy robot permanently stuck inside Harold's home as I could click on the house before the enemies were killed- Animals on the farm get stuck on their pens and on the other side of fences, if their pen is against a fence- Sometimes, no matter what you're hovering over, the game shows you a tooltip for the same item. You pick up whatever tooltip it's showing, which means no matter what I'm hovering over, it will pick up a potato

Review by  Gaming Masterpieces   - The greatest games of all time on Steam. Is this game a masterpiece? No, but it is a cute, relaxing fantasy farming game in Early Access. Start either with everything available from the start, or in adventure mode with easy and casual gameplay. So, where IS the challenge mode? I guess there is none, this is not that kind of game. So what is it? Well, you run around with an enormous tool. Kind of a vacuum claener, water hose and jack-hammer in one. You break up stuff, suck it into your inventory and put it in a recycler to build new stuff. You befriend animals to receive eggs, and find blueprints to craft new things. Your aim is to build and run a farm. Or a zen garden. Everything is full of trash, so you have to collect trash, recycle it, craft tons of items, cook food, plant seeds and water them... kind of a survival game without the survival part. Talk with animals, kill hostile (battery-run) animals, construct new buildings and furniture. You'll soon dicover new areas, all completely destroyed by humanity. Your goal is to restore them back to their original beauty, without trash and poison around. Wish this would be so easy in real life.   Conclusion:Casual, zen-like farming and building game. Collect trash and rebuild a world trashed and destroyed by humanity.

The world is covered in trash and you must hoover it up. You'll also need to befriend animals, grow crops, cook food, recycle trash, and help out the locals who have all mysteriously had their feet nailed to the ground and of course lack your magical vacuum cleaner. The game is enjoyable and chill, you can't really lose, but you can experience set-backs. I've been playing this game since it's first version in early access, and I've seen it develop and change over time. The devs are active and receptive to feedback, which is good because the game did have quite a few bugs and balance issues. MOST of those are fixed now, though at time of writing the game has only just gone 'full release' so there will probably be a couple bugs introduced with that update. But I have no doubt they'll be fixed quickly. All in all a fantastic game, and I have lost many many hours to it...

As it stands right now I would not recommend buying the game, as it has too many problems that still need fixing. It should not even be in full release before the majority of them are fixed tbh, the release was too rushed.-The controls feel awkward and clunky (even after they allegedly "fixed" some of it)-It is FAR too easy, with almost 80% of enemies/trash piles and explorable stuff removed since I tried it in early access, and on top of that it is also far too unbalanced with collecting quest items and resources (which you find too many of in almost all cases)-Trash piles randomly get stuck under ground or in the air and you can not reach them, as your drill and vacuum can not be tilted up or down (in most cases this is fixed by buying the best vacuum and going at it from weird angles to try and reach it, but is still a bug which should not happen)-You can literally soft lock your game on too many quests, because the game either does not register you do something for a quest (in case of 2 quests in the desert for example, where it does not register you putting stuff down or fixing something and is not resettable, of course) or it outright DESPAWNS THE QUEST ITEM (had that happen 2 times in Lonely Hills with the quest trash piles, that are only there for the quest, which despawned right after the quest for it was started so they could not be cleaned, thank you for that...)-Farm fields that are placed can lead to you falling through the map when you run over them (happens occasionally, no clue as to why and it also does not seem to matter where or how you place them)-The hitboxes for Animals, plants and enemies are badly placed and extremely frustrating, especially with your pet for which the hitbox seems to be floating somewhere above it, where you can trigger it (when you are lucky and look at the pet from the "right angle", wherever that is at the moment)- The story is just, disappointing really. The concept is ok, but there is nothing in it that makes it interesting and the changes from early acces to the "full release" also took it down a fair bit.This are only the major bugs I noticed in the 6 times I had to restart from a new save, as my game got soft locked by them, and frankly I don't have the patience or will to start over again to list every single one.The game has potential, yes, but it is not at all worth the price it stands at for the content you get. I bought it in early access for around 10€, which it was worth at that time from my perspective, as it was really fun and satisfying (even though a bit monotonous after a while, but I digress), but since the "full release" it dropped in value in comparison. From all the features that were removed ,which made the game more fun to explore, and with even more bugs than what it had in early access, sadly.If you want to try the game I would suggest to wait until they finally fixed all the major issues and then some (hopefully) or wait for a major discount, otherwise I would not waste my money on it.

Tunic is both rare and meticulous.Beautiful art design and a 'just-hard-enough' level of difficult combat combine well, as Tunic alights the imagination with a highly specific and unique reverence: one that speaks explicitly to the history of video games as a medium, what it was 'once like' to play them in a time lost to the ages, and what it was like to experience discovering a new one (lightly used). Once upon a time, people would rent video games from local retail stores. What came with any particular game, who could say. Sometimes, they would, like instruction books with passwords left in the notes section. A Mega Man save image map, hand drawn.These traces were the remnants of a run through the game left unfinished, lost to its original player and time, now in your hands for the first time. Tunic is a game that simulates such a feeling, compelling in its player a simple truth, slowly: you are not the first. But here is what someone else has learned.

I really wanted to like this game. The levels and character designs are so full of charm and interesting ideas, but ultimately the combat is just incredibly unenjoyable, even for someone like me who actually finished the entirety of Dark Souls. Everything you do feels sluggish, enemies attack faster than you can, the parry has an ungodly amount of start up for...some reason, and after a while enemies start doing more than half your HP in damage in a single hit, even less than an hour into the game (and your "Estus flasks" don't even restore half your HP bar, so you have about 3 hits before you're dead). And of course it takes me anywhere from 4 to 15 hits to take down an enemy sometimes. Usually 4, but when it gets higher than that, it gets incredibly tedious. It doesn't feel rewardingly challenging, it just feels like it wants you to be perfect. And this is EARLY in the game, there's NO way to upgrade myself any further yet.The game even locks what feel like core necessary gameplay features behind several challenges that, while difficult (or maybe even impossible, idk) to miss, just feel like a slog to get through without things like the ability to block.I'd like to give this game more of a chance, but honestly most of my criticisms just come down to "it feels really bad to play" and I'm running up against the window to refund it, so I'm going to have to stop here.I have read about what happens later in the game, and it's a shame, because that sounds like a part I would actually really enjoy, but I don't guess I'll ever make it there to find out.tl;dr: the game is heavy on hack-and-slash combat but it feels slow and unresponsive even for someone who's used to how slow and deliberate Dark Souls combat is, and everything does a lot of damage while you do very little, making it extra tedious on top of that.

Tunic easily rocketed to the top spot of my all-time favorite games, the art style is charming, the OST is absolutely stellar and something you can listen to for hours on end without so much as an inkling of repetitiveness, and the game's play style is utterly enthralling, every time I had to reluctantly put the controller down I immediately wanted to continue playing again. The game's fights progress in difficulty in a way that's not daunting, frustrating, or irrelevant with each new enemy and boss providing a unique experience that scales in a way you can simply feel your power and proficiency progress. The game's secrets are plentiful and range from in your face to galaxy brain, things that you'd never have even thought to consider prior that then open up entire new methods of thinking about the game and everything you've ever seen in it! Long story short -- the game is charming, clever, and you can tell just by playing a few minutes of it that an immense amount of time and love went into it's development. I wholeheartedly cannot recommend this game enough to anyone who likes open-world adventure, perplexing puzzles, and difficult combat. I love games with breeding and genetics. There is Pokemon, with IV breeding, Sonic Adventure with the Chao Garden, Planet Zoo... and then there is Wobbledogs.Wobbledogs scratches that itch in a way that the other games can't. At first glance the game doesn't look like much. It's very rectangular, very wobbly, the music is repetitive, and there isn't a significant amount to do. But it makes up for what it lacks in sheer number of legs. See, the point of the game is to crossbreed the lovable near-gelatinous dogs over and over until you've created an abomination worthy of its own entry in the Monster Manual, and from what I have seen the community is still debating on if there are any limitations besides your own hardware. You can just keep breeding more legs onto them. More heads. More tails. Or have a dog with 3 heads, one wing and no legs. I bred a table once.While the dogs(?) aren't having their DNA shoved into a breeding simulation machine of questionable reliability, they live in very cute and customizable habitat cubes that can be connected with hamster tunnels. Furniture items can be easily unlocked by capsule balls that are... dropped by your dogs(?), and there are many ways to create unique and fun habitats.Wobbledogs are also virtual pets requiring care and attention. You need to feed them, clean up their excretions, pupate them as they come of age, and account for their mobility issues as you breed them into non-functionality. What you feed them has an impact on how they grow and mutate, so you do need to take care with their diet. Your reward for this hard work is a single unfertilized egg, which can be used to make more abominations. After that they either live in storage for all eternity, or they exist until they die. If they die after you did a good job taking care of them, it rewards your other dogs(?) with a "feast". Actually it does that if you did a bad job. This game isn't very punishing.There is a very simple way to save and share your dogs, so you and your friends (or random strangers) can crossbreed your unique abominations together into some sort of obscene collaboration.Overall this is a really fun and addicting game. The art style grew on me, like extra legs, and the gameplay is simple and doesn't have much depth, but it is entertaining enough to hold my attention. While the music is catchy and really suits the game, it is incredibly repetitive and I feel it needs more tracks. Overall this game very quickly became one of my favorites and I plan to put many many hours into it.
